title-group.article-title: Knowledge, attitudes and practices regarding cervical cancer screening among women in the Dindaeng community, Bangkok, Thailand: a cross-sectional community-based study

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Faculty of Medicine, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand
2Srisavarindhira Thai Red Cross Institute of Nursing, Bangkok, Thailand
3Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, King Chulalongkorn Memorial Hospital, Bangkok, Thailand

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: To assess knowledge, attitudes and practices regarding cervical cancer screening among women in Bangkok’s Dindaeng community and identify factors influencing screening uptake.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Cross-sectional, community-based survey.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Primary care level; conducted in a high-density, low-income urban community in Bangkok, Thailand.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 450 women aged 25–65 years were recruited using convenience sampling. After excluding ineligible participants (eg, prior hysterectomy), 428 women completed the questionnaire. All participants were literate in Thai and resided in the study area.

sec.title: Primary and secondary outcome measures
sec.p: The primary outcome was a history of cervical cancer screening (ever screened vs never screened). Secondary outcomes included frequency of screening, barriers to screening and level of knowledge regarding cervical cancer and human papillomavirus (HPV).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Among 428 participants (mean age 47.9±11.2 years), 65.4% reported ever having been screened, but only 19.1% adhered to regular screening intervals. The most common barriers to screening were the absence of symptoms (54.7%) and fear of the procedure (42.1%). Only 31.8% correctly identified HPV as the cause of cervical cancer, and 23.8% were aware of the HPV vaccine. Higher knowledge scores were associated with having fewer children (adjusted OR (AOR) = 10.71; 95% CI: 1.29 to 89.12), while oral contraceptive use was negatively associated with high knowledge scores (AOR=0.14; 95% CI: 0.03 to 0.74).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Despite a moderate rate of screening uptake, consistent adherence and knowledge regarding cervical cancer and its prevention remain suboptimal. Targeted community health education and structural interventions are needed to improve awareness and promote regular screening in low-income urban settings.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: This study used a community-based design to assess real-world practices and barriers among women in an underserved urban population.
A structured, validated questionnaire was used, and reliability was pilot-tested prior to data collection.
Logistic regression was applied to identify factors associated with knowledge and screening behaviour.
Convenience sampling may limit the representativeness of the sample.
The exclusion of women who were not literate in Thai may have introduced selection bias.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cervical cancer remains a major global health concern, ranking among the leading causes of cancer-related deaths in women. In 2022, the International Agency for Research on Cancer of the WHO reported approximately 662 301 new cases and 348 874 deaths worldwide, with nearly 90% of fatalities occurring in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where access to screening and vaccination is often inadequate.1 2 In 2022, there were 8662 new cases and 4576 deaths from cervical cancer in Thailand. Age-standardised incidence rate (ASR) of cervical cancer in Thailand was 14.9.1 Despite Thailand’s national cervical cancer screening programme—where screening services including cytology (Pap smear), HPV testing, cotesting and visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) are widely available through district hospitals, health promotion centres and mobile clinics—participation rates vary significantly (46.3–70%),3 4 while the national target of screening was 70%.5 There is a lower uptake among women from disadvantaged backgrounds, underscoring persistent disparities in access and utilisation.6 According to the HPV Fact Sheet for Thailand, the coverage of cervical cancer screening among Thai women was as follows: 70% had been screened at least once in their lifetime, 59% had been screened in the past 5 years and 43% had been screened in the past 3 years.3 Although cervical cancer screening services—including cytology (Pap smear) or HPV testing, co-testing and VIA—are widely available through district hospitals, health promotion centres and mobile clinics, uptake remains suboptimal.

The primary cause of cervical cancer is persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV).4 In high-income countries, widespread HPV vaccination and routine screening, including Pap smears and HPV DNA testing, have significantly reduced cervical cancer incidence.5 Current guidelines from the Royal Thai College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists recommend cervical cancer screening for women aged 25–65 years, at intervals of 2–5 years depending on the method used. HPV vaccination is recommended for individuals aged 9–45 years (both males and females), with a focus on girls aged 11–12 years.6 7 However, in Thailand, HPV vaccination coverage remains low among eligible women, and many do not adhere to recommended screening guidelines, particularly those in low-income urban and rural areas.8 9 This gap in preventive healthcare increases the risk of late-stage cervical cancer diagnoses, leading to higher morbidity and mortality rates.

Bangkok, the capital city of Thailand, is a highly urbanised area with marked socioeconomic diversity. The Din Daeng district, located in central Bangkok, is one of the most densely populated communities in the city. With a total area of 8.354 square kilometres and a population of 122,563, the population density is approximately 14 590 persons per square kilometre, compared with the national average of 136 persons per square kilometre.10 The district is home to many low-income households and informal workers. Although public health services are available through local health promotion hospitals, barriers such as limited health literacy, overcrowded living conditions and inconsistent access to preventive care remain. Dindaeng exemplifies the challenges faced by urban low-income populations in accessing essential health services, including cervical cancer screening.11 Previous research highlights key barriers to screening participation, including financial constraints, limited awareness, cultural stigma, fear of procedures and misconceptions about cervical cancer.12 13 These factors contribute to low screening adherence and underutilisation of HPV vaccination programmes, exacerbating health disparities.

Despite national initiatives to promote cervical cancer screening, critical gaps in knowledge and screening adherence persist, particularly among marginalised communities. Most studies in Thailand focus on hospital-based populations, leaving a significant knowledge gap regarding real-world challenges in urban underserved settings.

This study aims to assess women’s knowledge of cervical cancer and its prevention in the Dindaeng community, evaluate screening uptake and adherence, identify barriers to participation and analyse demographic influences on screening behaviour. By identifying key determinants, the findings can inform targeted public health strategies to improve screening and vaccination rates in urban low-income areas. Strengthening community-driven initiatives, healthcare infrastructure and data collection systems is essential for ensuring equitable access. Addressing these gaps will ultimately contribute to reducing cervical cancer incidence and mortality among Thai women.

sec.title: Study design and Population
sec.p: This cross-sectional study was conducted in the Dindaeng community, in Bangkok, Thailand, from October to December 2024. Ethical approval was obtained from the Institutional Review Board of the Faculty of Medicine, Chulalongkorn University (IRB No. 0059/67). Eligible participants were women aged 25–65 years who resided in the community and were able to read and write Thai. Literacy was required to ensure independent completion of the self-administered questionnaire and to minimise interviewer bias. Women who had a history of cervical cancer, prior hysterectomy or difficulty in reading/writing were excluded.

The sample size was calculated based on a previous study conducted in a similar urban Thai population by Chaowawanit et al14, which examined cervical cancer screening behaviour and knowledge among women living in Bangkok.14 This prior study, conducted between 2014 and 2015, reported a screening adequacy proportion of 0.43 and a good knowledge proportion of 0.26. Using these parameters, a 95% confidence level and a 5% margin of error, the required sample sizes were calculated to be 377 and 296, respectively. To account for a potential 20% non-response rate, the final sample size was set at 450 participants.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The questionnaire (online supplemental file 1) was developed in Thai and validated for content by two gynaecologic oncologists. A pilot test for reliability was conducted among 10 volunteers from a nearby community. The original version was not translated into English as the study population was exclusively Thai-speaking.

Community leaders and health volunteers were oriented on the study flow and the questionnaire content to support participant engagement. A convenience sampling method was employed. Eligible women were recruited through community centres and home visits in collaboration with local health workers. All recruitment, eligibility screening and consent procedures were carried out by trained research nurses. Women were screened for eligibility based on age (25–65 years), residency and literacy in Thai. Written informed consent was obtained prior to participation. Data collection took place at community health stations or participants’ homes, depending on convenience.
Participants completed a structured, self-administered questionnaire, which included items on demographics, knowledge of cervical cancer and HPV, screening history and perceived barriers.

Chronic disease status was assessed by asking participants if they had any underlying conditions, followed by a checklist of common diseases (eg, hypertension, diabetes) and given the option to list additional conditions in an open-ended format.

Knowledge assessment was based on 15 multiple-choice questions covering cervical cancer risk factors, HPV, screening guidelines and HPV vaccination. Each correct answer was awarded one point. Total scores were converted to percentages and categorised into three levels: low (<50%), moderate (50–69%) and high (70–100%).

Screening behaviour outcomes were assessed using self-reported questionnaire items. Lifetime screening was determined by the question, ‘Have you ever had a cervical cancer screening?’ Up-to-date screening status was based on whether participants had undergone screening within the past 3 years. Regular screening was defined as self-reported screening at 1–3-year intervals, in accordance with previous national guidelines recommending cytology-based screening in the population.15

Barriers to screening were assessed using a structured list of commonly reported obstacles derived from previous studies. Participants were asked to respond yes/no to each listed item, which included misconceptions (eg, ‘I don’t need screening if I have no symptoms’), psychological concerns (eg, fear of pain or embarrassment) and logistical challenges (eg, time, cost or distance).

Data were anonymised and analysed using SPSS version 22. Descriptive statistics summarised participant characteristics, and logistic regression analysis was used to identify factors associated with screening participation.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Patients and members of the public were not involved in the design, conduct, analysis or dissemination of this study. However, community leaders and local health volunteers supported participant recruitment and facilitated community engagement.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 450 women participated in the study, with 22 being excluded due to prior hysterectomy, leaving 428 participants for final analysis. table 1 presents the general characteristics of participants, disaggregated by cervical cancer screening history.

caption.title: Sociodemographic characteristics of participants by screening history

tr.td: No formal educationPrimary schoolLower secondary schoolUpper secondary school or equivalentDiploma or equivalentBachelor’s degreeHigher than Bachelor’s degree
Less than 10 00010 000–30 00030 001–50 00050 001 and aboveNot willing to disclose

fn.p: IUD, intrauterine device; OCP, Oral contraceptive pills ; TR, tubal resection.

sec.p: The mean age of the participants was 47.89 years (SD=11.2). Women who had ever been screened were younger on average (43.65 years) than those who had never been screened (49.64 years). A greater proportion of women who had ever been screened were married (59.6%) compared with never-screened women (42.6%). Freelance/self-employment was the most common occupation overall and among both groups. Screening uptake appeared slightly more common among women with higher education levels and among those with health insurance.

Among the 428 participants, 280 (65.4%) reported ever having been screened for cervical cancer, while 148 (34.5%) had never undergone screening. Regular screening (defined as every 1–3 years) was reported by 82 women (29.3% of those screened). table 2 details the frequency of screening.

caption.title: Frequency of cervical cancer screening among participants

sec.p: table 3 outlines the reported reasons for not undergoing cervical cancer screening. The most common reasons among never-screened participants were absence of symptoms (71.6%), fear related to the examination (55.4%) and belief of being at low risk (23.0%). Significant differences in barriers were observed between the ever- and never-screened groups for multiple factors, including lack of awareness (p<0.001), fear (p<0.001), and perceived lack of necessity (p=0.002).

caption.title: Attitudes and perceived barriers to screening

tr.td: Uncertainty about where to get screened
Belief of being at low risk
Fear of bleeding or excessive discharge
Concern about unclean equipment or infection
Fear of discovering abnormalities or cancer
Concerns related to the COVID-19 pandemic

sec.p: Knowledge of cervical cancer, HPV and screening was assessed using 15 items, with each correct response awarded one point (maximum score=15). Total scores were converted to percentages and categorised into three levels: low (< 50%), moderate (50–69%) and high (70–100%). The mean (SD) total score was 3.2 (2.96), and the median (IQR) was 2 (1–5). Only 10 participants (2.3%) achieved a high score (70–100%), indicating generally poor knowledge in this population. Only 31.8% of participants correctly identified HPV as the primary cause of cervical cancer. Awareness of HPV vaccination was also limited, with only 23.8% knowing that vaccination could prevent cervical cancer. Regarding screening knowledge, only 10.5% of participants knew the recommended screening frequency and 8.2% understood the appropriate age to begin screening.

Multivariable logistic regression (table 4) identified several key factors associated with cervical cancer screening uptake. Women under 29 years old were significantly less likely to have been screened compared with those aged 60 or older (AOR=0.28; 95% CI: 0.11 to 0.71; p<0.01). A history of underlying disease was positively associated with screening participation (AOR=1.84; 95% CI: 1.13 to 3.00; p=0.01). Contraceptive use, marital status and education level were significantly associated with screening in the univariable analysis but did not remain significant in the multivariable model, suggesting potential confounding effects by other variables.

caption.title: Significant factors associated with cervical cancer screening uptake (multivariable logistic regression)

tr.td: Government officer/state enterprise employee/private company employee

sec.p: Furthermore, multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed that having one or no children was strongly associated with higher knowledge scores (AOR=10.71, 95% CI: 1.29 to 89.12). In contrast, the use of oral contraceptives was negatively associated with achieving a high knowledge score (AOR=0.14, 95% CI: 0.03 to 0.74).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study highlights significant gaps in knowledge and practices—and attitudinal barriers such as fear, embarrassment and misconceptions about the need for screening—related to cervical cancer screening among women in the Dindaeng community, an underserved urban area in Bangkok. Dindaeng was selected as the study site due to its high population density, socioeconomic disadvantages and limited access to healthcare services—characteristics that make it representative of urban communities at heightened risk for low screening uptake.

Although the overall screening rate (65.4%) aligns with national estimates, only 29.3% of those screened adhered to recommended screening intervals. This gap in regular screening suggests that while awareness of screening exists, consistent participation remains a challenge. The lifetime screening rate of 65.4%, although comparable to previous studies in urban Thailand, remains suboptimal when considering national goals for cervical cancer elimination. This may reflect better access in an urban setting and possibly an overestimation due to the inclusion of only literate participants, who may be more likely to engage in screening.

sec.title: Screening behaviour and influencing factors
sec.p: The cervical cancer screening rate in this study, at 65.4%, is consistent with national estimates from previous Thai studies, which report screening rates ranging from 46% to 64%. However, this figure still falls short of Thailand’s national screening target of 70%. While the majority of participants had undergone screening at least once in their lifetime, only 19.1% adhered to the recommended screening intervals. For comparison, the HPV Fact Sheet for Thailand reports that 43% of women had been screened within the past 3 years. Although multiple screening methods—including cytology, HPV testing, cotesting and VIA—are available in Thailand, overall adherence to regular screening remains suboptimal.3 These findings reflect a need for improved strategies to promote regular screening behaviour, especially in underserved urban communities. Similar patterns have been observed in other Southeast Asian countries, where cervical cancer screening tends to be infrequent rather than routine.16 The irregularity in screening behaviours may be attributed to several factors, including a low perceived risk of cervical cancer, misconceptions about the necessity of screening when symptoms are absent and systemic barriers such as limited access to healthcare and financial constraints.

Women who had ever been screened tended to be younger, married and more educated. Multivariable analysis confirmed that women with a history of sexual intercourse were nearly ten times more likely to have been screened. This aligns with the rationale for screening targeting sexually active women and highlights the need for early engagement.

Interestingly, women under 29 were significantly less likely to be screened. This may reflect inadequate risk perception among younger women or a lack of targeted messaging. A positive association between underlying diseases and screening suggests that contact with healthcare services facilitates preventive behaviours.

sec.title: Knowledge regarding cervical cancer prevention
sec.p: Knowledge gaps about cervical cancer and HPV were substantial, with only 31.8% of participants correctly identifying HPV as the primary cause of cervical cancer. Similar low awareness levels have been reported in other Thai studies, as well as in neighbouring countries such as Vietnam and Indonesia.111722 Although 23.8% of participants were aware that HPV vaccination could prevent cervical cancer, this figure remains far below the knowledge levels seen in high-income countries, where vaccination awareness campaigns have been more effective.23 Increasing HPV education through school-based and community health initiatives could significantly improve vaccine uptake and, ultimately, reduce cervical cancer incidence.

The finding that only 10.5% of participants understood the recommended frequency of cervical cancer screening underscores a broader issue of inadequate dissemination of screening guidelines. Previous studies have demonstrated that even among women who have undergone screening, many lack a clear understanding of when they should return for subsequent tests.24 25 Public health campaigns should not only promote initial screening but also emphasise the importance of repeat screening at regular intervals.

sec.title: Barriers and misconceptions
sec.p: The most prevalent barrier identified was the misconception that cervical cancer screening is unnecessary in the absence of symptoms. This belief was reported by 71.6% of never-screened women and 45.7% of those who had been screened, highlighting a significant and widespread knowledge gap. Consistent with findings from other LMICs,1517 this misconception often led participants to delay or forgo screening altogether. Addressing this barrier through targeted, community-based education emphasising the importance of early detection even in asymptomatic individuals is critical.

The second most commonly reported barrier was fear of the screening procedure itself, including concerns about pain, embarrassment and the risk of infection. These anxieties were reported by 55.4% of never-screened women and 35.0% of those who had been screened (p<0.001), highlighting psychosocial deterrents to screening. Often shaped by cultural norms and misconceptions about gynaecological exams, these concerns reinforce the importance of delivering health education in a culturally sensitive and community-specific manner to promote screening uptake.14 26

Logistical issues (eg, time, cost, distance) were less frequently reported but still relevant. Although Thailand provides free cervical cancer screening through its Universal Health Coverage system, indirect costs such as transportation, lost wages and childcare responsibilities may prevent women from attending screening appointments. Mobile units, flexible clinic hours and screening incorporated into primary care visits can address these structural barriers.27

Furthermore, women with one or no children were significantly more likely to achieve high knowledge scores related to cervical cancer and its prevention, possibly due to fewer caregiving responsibilities and greater opportunity to engage in health education. Conversely, although contraceptive use was associated with a higher likelihood of screening participation, it was negatively linked with knowledge levels. This contrast suggests that while family planning services may effectively deliver screening, they might insufficiently address cervical cancer education. These findings highlight the complex interplay between reproductive history, contraceptive behaviour, health literacy and preventive practices, reinforcing the need for integrated education strategies within reproductive health and primary care settings.

sec.title: Policy implications
sec.p: The findings from this study underscore the urgent need for targeted interventions to improve cervical cancer screening rates and knowledge in underserved urban communities. Policymakers should consider expanding community-based education programmes, integrating cervical cancer screening into routine primary healthcare visits and increasing mobile screening services to reach women facing access barriers.

Additionally, evidence-based strategies—such as digital health tools (eg, SMS reminders), social media campaigns and provider-led community outreach—may also be effective in improving screening adherence and addressing misinformation surrounding cervical cancer prevention.28 29

sec.title: Study strengths and limitations
sec.p: This study provides valuable insights into the real-world barriers to cervical cancer screening in a low-income urban setting, using a community-based approach and a large sample size. The use of a validated questionnaire and multivariate analysis strengthens the reliability of the findings.

However, several limitations should be acknowledged. First, the cross-sectional design prevents causal inferences between knowledge levels and screening behaviours. Future longitudinal studies are needed to track screening adherence over time. Second, the study was conducted in a single urban community, limiting its generalisability to other Thai populations, particularly those in rural areas. Comparative studies between urban and rural populations would be beneficial. Third, self-reported data may be subject to recall bias or social desirability bias, particularly regarding screening history. Future studies could use medical records to validate self-reported screening behaviours. Fourth, the requirement for participants to read and write Thai in order to complete the self-administered questionnaire may have excluded non-literate individuals, particularly those from disadvantaged or migrant backgrounds. While literacy rates in Bangkok are estimated to be over 97%, this criterion may have limited the generalisability of the findings to the entire community.

sec.title: Future research directions
sec.p: To build on these findings, future work should evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of evidence-based interventions to increase cervical cancer screening in underserved communities. In addition, qualitative studies could offer valuable insights into cultural and psychological factors influencing screening uptake.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite moderate screening rates, substantial knowledge gaps and misconceptions persist among women in these community-based urban settings. Addressing barriers related to access, misinformation and fear through targeted health education programmes and community-based interventions could improve screening adherence. Increasing HPV vaccination awareness and making screening services more accessible through community healthcare and flexible clinic hours should be prioritised in future public health efforts.

fn.p: Funding: This work was funded by Thailand Science Research and Innovation (grant number HEAF67300053).
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2025-100896).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.

Ethics approval: This study involves human participants and was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Faculty of Medicine, Chulalongkorn University (IRB No. 0059/67). Participants gave informed consent to participate in the study before taking part.

Data availability free text: The datasets generated and/or analyzed during the current study are not publicly available due to ethical restrictions and participant confidentiality, but are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. Requests will be considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with institutional data sharing policies.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination plans of this research.
